awd_titl_txt: Adsorption and Self-Assembly of Surfactants on Metallic Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
The research project will employ experimental techniques and computer simulations to study the adsorption and self-assembly of surfactant molecules on metal-water interfaces, and their effect on the electrochemical nature of the interfaces. Corrosion-related failure of oil and gas pipelines is a significant health, safety, financial, and environmental problem. Surfactant molecules with imidazoline, amine and amido-amine based polar groups and hydrophobic alkyl chains are known to strongly adsorb and self-assemble onto metallic surfaces. These molecules are useful as inhibitors of corrosion in oil and gas pipelines. It is suggested that the self-assembled adsorbed films of these molecules mitigate corrosion by either repelling the corrosive species from metal-water interfaces, by rendering the interface hydrophobic, or by changing the electrochemical nature of the interface.  Electrochemical experimental techniques will be employed to measure changes in electrical properties of metallic interfaces upon adsorption. The experimental results, combined with molecular simulations, will provide a comprehensive molecular picture of the phenomena. This level of understanding will be a significant step towards improving the methodologies of designing more effective corrosion inhibitor molecules for various applications.

The phenomenon of adsorption and self-assembly of surfactants on metallic surfaces is fundamentally important for many catalysis and electrochemical applications. Because of high polarizability of metals, interactions between metals and polar molecules depend on the local environment. While there have been exciting new developments in improving our knowledge of metal-water interfaces, there are significant gaps in our understanding of the molecular-level details of adsorption of surfactant molecules on metallic surfaces. Many aspects of the phenomenon are only vaguely understood, such as the nature of binding between metal atoms and surfactant molecules; molecular orientation and packing in adsorbed films; factors promoting self-assembly; and the electrochemical nature of the interface. Using experimental techniques, such as electrochemical quartz crystal microbalance (EQCM), atomic force microscopy (AFM), sum frequency generation spectroscopy (SFG), electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and molecular simulations, the investigators seek to address each of these unknowns in the proposed research. In addition to training graduate and undergraduate students on interdisciplinary research projects, the investigators plan to pursue outreach activities in the Appalachian region of Ohio to provide an avenue for the citizens of this economically disadvantaged area to advance via education.

por.por_cntn:
Surfactants or soap-like molecules bind or adsorb onto metal surfaces to form a layer that helps in retarding corrosion, that is rust formation, of these surfaces. Therefore, these molecules are used as inhibitors of corrosion of oil and gas transportation pipelines that are made up of mild steel. However, unexpected corrosion-related failures of the pipelines still occur because we do not know the optimum chemical make-up of surfactant molecules that will result in the formation of physically robust layers capable of withstanding different flow and environmental conditions. The goal of this project is to perform experiments and computer simulations to uncover the relationship between the chemical make-up of surfactant molecules and the physical and chemical properties of the adsorbed layers that they form over metal surfaces. The results will help in developing new molecules useful as corrosion inhibitors. Surfactant molecules have a water-loving (polar) part and a water-repelling (hydrophobic) part. The polar part of the molecule is understood to have strong binding to metal surfaces, and the hydrophobic part forms a water-repelling barrier in the adsorbed layer.  The main scientific and broader impact outcomes are the following:

1. We developed a laboratory procedure to chemically synthesize surfactants with different polar groups (chemical names: benzyl dimethyl ammonium, benzyl trimethyl ammonium, and imidazolines), with the hydrophobic part of varying lengths. The hydrophobic part resembles oil molecules or linear alkanes. We also developed laboratory procedures to characterize the purity of these surfactants.

2. We developed new experimental methodologies using a technique called sum frequency generation (SFG) spectroscopy to determine the spatial arrangement of surfactant molecules at the air-water and metal-water interfaces.

3. Using both SFG experiments and computer simulations, we showed that the hydrophobic part of surfactants plays an important role in forming a tightly packed adsorbed layer on metal surfaces. When the hydrophobic part is small, the amount of surfactant binding on the surfaces is reduced, and so the corrosion inhibition is inadequate.  

4. Above a certain concentration, surfactant molecules are known to aggregate in organized structures to hide their hydrophobic part from water. These aggregates are called micelles and the concentration is called the critical micelle concentration (CMC). We experimentally measured the CMC of different surfactants and showed that the concentration at which the metal surface gets fully covered with surfactants may be much smaller than the CMC, and so for these surfactants, one can use smaller concentrations to retard corrosion.

5. Using an experimental technique to measure molecular-level forces between a probe tip and adsorbed molecules, called atomic force microscopy (AFM), we measured thickness of the adsorbed layer of surfactants at different solution concentrations. We found that at small concentrations, only a part of the surface is covered by surfactants. At higher concentrations, the surface is fully covered with two layers of surfactants in which the molecules are arranged in an interdigitated manner. These results matched our observations made using computer simulations.

6. Using computer simulations, we showed that the micelles of surfactants adsorb strongly on the metal surface by disintegrating on the surface. If surfactants are electrically charged, the micelles experience some repulsion from the surface, but once they overcome this repulsion, they strongly adsorb via disintegration.

7. We developed a new mathematical theory that predicts the arrangement of adsorbed surfactant molecules at the metal surface given the shape of the molecule and the affinity of the polar and the hydrophobic part of the molecule for the surface. We validated our theory via computer simulations.

8. We showed, via experiments and computer simulations, that oil molecules can adsorb along with the surfactant molecules on the metal surfaces, and due to this co-adsorption, more densely packed and water-repelling layers are formed.

9. Using both AFM and computer simulations, we found that the surfactants can completely cover metal surfaces with adsorbed layers even when patches of the surfaces have little affinity for the surfactants. Our computer simulations showed that this phenomenon occurs because of the strong packing of hydrophobic parts of the surfactants in these layers.

10. The researchers involved in the project gave Science Café talks to disseminate their research findings to the community. The researchers participated in organizing district science fairs every year for middle- and high-school students, as well as in the Experience Engineering and Technology days organized at Ohio University.

11. The research findings were disseminated via scientific publications and conference presentations. Two graduate students involved in this research got research awards and two graduate students got awarded research fellowships by the university. Three graduate students successfully defended their Ph.Ds.

12.  The researchers participated in the Program to Aid Career Exploration (PACE) at Ohio University to recruit many undergraduate students as researchers on this project.
